class_notes:
(Same as CHN 260 1, EAS 260 1, KRN 260 1)
This course is an introduction to the modern history of one of the world's most dynamic and important regions: East Asia. Taught by two professors, one who specializes in China and one who specializes in Korea, it introduces the main events, processes, and issues of East Asian history from around 1500 to the present. It is intended for students who are interested in the region and would like some historical background. It is also good gateway course for students who are considering majoring or minoring in East Asian Studies.
The course aims to provide basic background on the history of East Asia, focusing on how the individual states within the region; most importantly China, Korea, and Japan, interacted with each other and with the wider world, while developing perceptions of East Asia and the world.
course_description: This course will emphasize transnational aspects of East Asian history, focusing on how the East Asian international system interacted with Southeast Asia, South Asia, Inner Asia, as well as with Europe and the U.S. from 1500 to the present.
